The Universe is 13.8 billion years old and the edge of the Observable Universe is 46.5 billion light years away, how do you explain that. We know we are not seeing what it was like 46.5 billion years ago, since time and it didn’t exist then!
Imagine you had 25 people standing in 5 lines of 5 to represent the singularity, then free space grew by 1 metre between each of them so they would now all be a metre apart. The middle did not move faster than the edges because none of the people actually moved in free space. There was relative velocity between the people but no real velocity since none of them had actually moved through free space. If originally the 25 people were standing on black crosses, they would still be standing on the same black crosses after the expansion. Each person had a zero displacement, therefore zero velocity. Whichever person was the observer, they would see all the other people going away from them, the people furthest from them would have had the biggest relative velocity to them. Imagine you were a person at the end of one of these lines of 5 people. The nearest person to you would have moved an extra 1 metre from you while the person at the other end of the line would have moved 4 metres from you. If you now imagined there were millions of people and they all moved an extra metre apart due to the expansion of free space between each of them how the furthest person could have had a RELATIVE velocity exceeding the speed of light. This also explains why the edge of our Observable Universe is about 46.5 billion light years away even though the Universe is only 13.8 billion years old. The most distant galaxies didn’t have to move faster than the speed of light in a vacuum, it was free space expanding the space-time away from us faster than the speed of light that enabled them to be that far away.

The size of the Hubble sphere is a function of the current rate of expansion of the universe, i.e., the Hubble Constant. The bigger the Hubble Constant, the smaller the Hubble sphere, and vice versa. In the early universe, the expansion rate was very high and thus the Hubble sphere was very small: Most of our current observable universe was outside the Hubble sphere: Light from those objects was getting farther away over time as it was not able to make headway on its journey towards Earth (or where Earth would eventually form). But, due to gravity, the expansion rate was rapidly slowing: The Hubble sphere was rapidly growing. Over time, light that was outside the Hubble sphere crossed the boundary to be inside the Hubble sphere, and could eventually reach the Earth and be observed, albeit with a significant redshift (stretching of its wavelength due to the expansion of space). But later, due to dark energy, the expansion rate of the universe began to accelerate: The Hubble sphere began to contract. As dark energy will continue to increase as the universe expands, the expansion rate will also continue to increase from now on, and the Hubble sphere will continue to shrink. Light that is now outside the Hubble sphere will always remain outside the Hubble sphere. We are able to now see objects that are outside the Hubble sphere only because light they had emitted billions of years ago was lucky enough to cross inside the Hubble sphere during the time the expansion rate was slowing, and the Hubble sphere was growing. But now, the expansion rate is accelerating and will continue to do so for all remaining time: The Hubble sphere will continue to shrink for all remaining time. Objects that are outside the Hubble sphere will eventually disappear from our observable universe, no matter how long we wait.

So if we measure 3D space by "volume", then while the universe "expands", we notice that particles don't increase in volume or mass. Nothing is being "stretched thin" like you would expect. Take a sealed sphere. It has a set volume, and a finite amount of mass that exists within it. If you stretch or expand that sphere, you're not creating more mass, but rather stretching the distance between all atoms so that your mass fills your volume. Apply that to the universe. We don't see our world getting stretched out, yet we say the universe is expanding. Those two things would contradict each other. But that also means that the universe would have a finite volume, even if we can't see it or detect it yet. And to take that one step further, we say nothing can be created or destroyed, only change from one form to another. Meaning you can't create matter from nothing, or have matter permanently disappear from existence. That means the universe has a finite amount of mass. That also means that if it's expanding, because it's finite, in order to take up more volume (while maintaining mass), it would have to expand INTO something else, thus, gaining volume. Now if we say that the universe isn't expanding "into" anything, it's just expanding, then we've clearly come to the conclusion that there is a separation between "nothing" and "the universe". If the universe was literally ALL there is, then it would have no need to expand, as it would already occupy all of existence, making expansion meaningless. If that's the case, that means that what we observe as expansion, could actually be everything being COMPRESSED, giving the illusion of an "expanding" universe.

I'm often left in awe of our universe and it's mechanics. And this show does an amazing job of delivering these priceless bits of knowledge to us. However, I need to comment on what I just watched. Bearing in mind that this is coming from a man with no formal degree or qualification in astronomy or science beyond a GCSE level, but something didn't sit right with me. The Hubble Sphere, and the light from distant galaxies that originate from outside of the sphere, becoming sub-luminal as the Hubble Sphere expands. It's safe to assume that Earth's position within the Hubble Sphere is fixed, as the Sphere is relative to us. We are always in the centre, as we are the observers. We cannot move from our fixed central position, because any shift we make, alters the horizon. Much like being in an open space where you can see the curvature of the Earth, then moving towards it. You never see past the curve itself, as the curve is relative to your position. So with that being said, our ability to observe light from beyond the horizon of the Hubble Sphere would be akin to seeing around the curvature of the Earth, not possible. The space within the Sphere expanding would not take the horizon and stretch it, as the horizon is relative to our ability to see that far. It's fixed. Take for example a sheet off stretchy material, pre-stretch. and you place a hoop on it to represent the horizon of the Hubble Sphere. You the stretch the material to replicate the expansion of the universe. The expansion takes place uniformly within and without the horizon, but never altering the horizon.

Again, I have no doctorate or PhD, I'm just a keyboard warrior with a bone to pick, but to suggest we can see past the observable universe because we're expanding into it seems to be untrue. Just like I can't see past the horizon without changing my vantage point, and therefore, changing the position of the horizon. What does seem to be true, is that for us to observe light from beyond the horizon of the Hubble Sphere, is if we travelled towards it. But this only shifts the horizon we experience, never truly expanding it. As we move in one direction towards the edge, we're moving away from the opposite edge.

You CANNOT talk about where the distant matter you see in the distance is "now" on the stipulation that the light you see from it was emitted 13.8 billion light-years ago, because there IS no "now" for it. Simultaneity is not defined across vast distances, that's special relativity 101, so there's no such thing as "right now" for it. But it's even worse than that, since if you were to try to find any meaningful estimate of where it is right now, you would find the answer to be infinity, because it has gone past the static limit, and is no longer causally connected to you, i.e. if you emitted a beam of light toward it, it would never reach it at all. So the only thing you can actually talk about with integrity is where the stuff you see was, when the light you see was emitted, and that was, of course, 13.8 billion light-years away. So the universe "is" 27.6 billion light-years across. Electromagnetic energy (light) is the only carrier of information and energy throughout the universe. If we do not receive light from it then it is unknowable. We cannot see things travelling faster than light because light needs time to propagate wavelengths and frequencies (frequency=time). If the speed-of-light was infinite there would be no frequency or wavelength and no light. It is that simple. Light itself cannot exceed 'c'. At the beginning of the universe there was no light until the formation of the first stars after billions of years of expansion. Therefore, we cannot ever see the edge of the universe because there was no light.

"For example in a decelerating Friedmann universe the Hubble sphere expands with time, and its boundary overtakes light emitted by more distant galaxies so that light emitted at earlier times by objects outside the Hubble sphere still may eventually arrive inside the sphere and be seen by us. Conversely, in an accelerating universe, the Hubble sphere shrinks with time, and its boundary overtakes light emitted by nearer galaxies so that light emitted at earlier times by objects inside the Hubble sphere will eventually recede outside the sphere and will never be seen by us. The reason we can see light from objects outside the Hubble Sphere is that sometime in the distant past, those objects were inside our Hubble sphere, and the light emitted from them took that entire time to get to us. The explanation for why this isn't a violation is not accurate. You can't measure speed of something relative to space. That would, in itself, be a fundamental violation of relativity principles. The reason why two distant objects can move apart faster than light is because speed of light limit is a local one. Without getting into mathematical details, two nearby objects can never be moving relative to each other faster than light. Furthermore, I could keep adding objects, and still no pair of nearby objects would be moving faster than light relative to each other. If space was not expanding, and there was no curvature, this would imply a global speed of light limit. If two objects far apart were receding faster than light in a non-expanding universe, I could place grains of sand in between moving in such a way as to cause some two nearby grains of sand to move faster than light relative to each other - a contradiction. However, because universe is expanding, this condition can be violated. Another example is rotating black hole, where an object passing through the ergosphere can move faster than light relative to objects a bit further from the black hole. Finally, the theoretical concept for warp drive exploits this property to allow a ship to travel faster than light without ever violating the locality.

The biggest misconception is the belief that the red shift of distant galaxies is a Doppler effect. Light from distant objects in the universe does not travel towards us in a straight line. The light expands outwards from a source in all directions simultaneously. That light is effected by gravitation from all of the mass within that sphere. All of the mass inside the sphere pulls the light back towards the source. All of the mass outside the sphere cancels out because any pull in a given direction is canceled by a similar pull in the opposite direction. The result is a gravitational red shift which creates the illusion that space is expanding.

Time Is relevant, Newton's view on time kept it separate from space. When Albert Einstein introduced his Theory of Relativity in the early 20th century, however, he suggested that time wasn't separate from space but connected to it. Time and space combined to form space-time, and everyone measures his or her own experience in it differently because the speed of light (300,000 km per second) is the same for all observers. In other words, if all observers have to agree on the speed of light being 300,000 km per second, then they can't agree on the time it takes for other objects to travel relative to them.
Einstein also suggested that space-time wasn't flat, but curved or "warped" by the existence of matter and energy. Large bodies in space-time, like the Earth, aren't just floating in orbit. Instead, imagine an apple resting on a stretched out blanket -- the weight of the apple warps the sheet. If the Earth is an apple, then we can imagine the Earth's blanket as space-time.
This means that someone moving through space-time will experience it differently at various points. Time will actually appear to move slower near massive objects, because space-time is warped by the weight. These predictions have actually been proven. In 1962, scientists placed two atomic clocks at the bottom and top of a water tower. The clock at the bottom, the one closer to the massive center of the Earth, was running slower than the clock at the top. Einstein called this phenomenon time dilation.
A further explanation of the bending of space-time and time dilation came in the form of a thought experiment called the twin paradox, devised in 1911 by French physicist Paul Langevin. If one twin lives at the foot of a mountain and the other lives at the top, the twin closer to the Earth will age more slowly. He or she would turn out younger than the other twin, though by a very small amount. If you sent one twin in a spaceship accelerating close to the speed of light, however, he or she would return much younger than the other twin, because high acceleration and large gravitational masses are the same in relativity. Of course, no one's gone so far as to send somebody's twin into high-speed orbit, but scientists proved the hypothesis true in the '70s by sending an atomic clock into orbit. It returned to Earth having run much slower than grounded atomic clocks

The universe is not infinite in size.

If the universe was once a finite size (and a singularity would by
definition be a finite size, i.e. zero), and the universe is now of
infinite size, then the universe would need an infinite amount of time,
at any finite growth rate, to move from one state to the other.

But if the universe grew at an infinite rate, it would be bigger than any finite size instantaneously. It would take zero time to grow into whatever size it may be, even infinite size.

So here we are in a logical paradox, were the universe must be both of infinite age, and of zero age, at the same time. (And of course, neither of these ages is 13.8 billion years, so you cannot believe in an infinite universe and the Big Bang theory at the same time - they are incompatible.)

Conclusion: the universe is of finite size.

(I suppose this is just an exercise in why the inclusion of the concept of infinity in any discussion of the natural world is a mistake. Infinity is a product of the mismatch our abstract creation - math - and concrete reality.)

"The theory is based on the concept of the Doppler Effect, but there's a hole in this reasoning."

Well NO! The theory is definitely not based on Doppler Effect redshift, and there is definitely not any hole in the reasoning.
Observational cosmology is certainly based on redshift, but the cosmological redshift of the expanding universe has nothing whatever to do with the Doppler Effect or the relative velocities of galaxy and observer through a medium. Cosmological redshift is the ratio of the scale factor of the universe when the photon is observed, to the scale factor in the past when it was emitted. It is solely an increase in the wave length of the light in direct proportion to the expansion of the space it traveled through.

There are various physical mechanisms of redshift, of which only one is cosmological in origin. But none of them are in any way related to the atmospheric reddening of light at sunset, which is not in fact redshift at all. Anyone interested in finding out what redshift actually is can check out the Wikipedia article on the subject which clearly illustrates the shift in absorption lines which is a defining feature of the redshift phenomenon. A simple reddening of light is not redshift.

@ Brad McClurg: Expanding space cosmology is a theory which is based in General Relativity. There was a time when Hawking believed  that the "hot dense state" big bang could be described as a gravitational singularity, within the scope of the Penrose-Hawking singularity theorems of General Relativity. But by the time of his 1988 book, "A Brief History of Time," Hawking had changed his mind, in favor of a Quantum description of the hot dense state. Here is what Hawking wrote more than 25 years ago:

"The final result was a joint paper by Penrose and myself in 1970, which at last proved that there must have been a big bang singularity provided only that general relativity is correct and the universe contains as much matter as we observe....So in the end our work became generally accepted and nowadays nearly everyone assumes that the universe started with a big bang singularity. It is perhaps ironic that, having changed my mind, I am now trying to convince other physicists that there was in fact no singularity at the beginning of the universe - as we shall see later, it can disappear once quantum effects are taken into account."

Hawking's view in 1988 is now a more widely accepted view of the big bang. Namely, that General Relativity does not provide an adequate physical description of the big bang as a gravitational singularity, and that a Quantum theory of gravity, if and when such a theory emerges, will provide a better insight into the physical nature and properties of the hot dense state of the big bang.

We see very distant galaxies in the Observable Universe in light which has traveled from the distant past, when the galaxies were much nearer to the earth than they are now. For example, NASA announced in May the most distant galaxy from the earth which has ever been spectroscopically confirmed. It has been designated EGS-zs8-1, and the redshift of its light has been spectroscopically measured as Z=7.73. The travel time of the light from this galaxy to the earth (called the "lookback time") was 13.1 billion light years (95% of the current age of the universe). When the galaxy emitted the light, it was located only 3.4 billion light years from the earth. In the 13.1 billion years that it took the light to get to the earth, the galaxy has been carried outward with expanding space to its present position 29.6 billion light years from the earth.


So the direct answer to your question about how it is that we can see light NOW that has traveled for 14 billion years from objects that are 14 billion light years away is that we can't. It doesn't work that way in an expanding spacetime. In this case, the light finally got to the earth after traveling 13.1 billion years from the distant past when the galaxy was MUCH nearer at 3.4 billion light years, and is now located MUCH farther away at 29.6 billion light years.


Only in a static spacetime, such as within the gravitationally bound stars of the Milky Way (where spacetime does not expand), can we infer, for example, that a light travel TIME of 10,000 years correctly infers a DISTANCE of 10,000 light years. That works for our local STATIC spacetime within a couple of million light years out to Andromeda for example, but it does not work at the vast distances of EXPANDING spacetime across distances of hundreds of millions....and billions of light years between distant galaxies.
 

We see galaxies in the observable universe of today which emitted light in the distant past when they were closer to the earth; and while their light traveled to the earth, they have moved outward to greater distances. From the standpoint of the light photons, they have moved through their local spacetime toward the earth at the universal constant speed of light, while they have simultaneously been swept outward from the earth with expanding spacetime. (They are always swimming against the current of expanding spacetime.) That's why, in this example, it took the light 13.1 billion years to get to the earth across an expanding distance of space that was only 3.4 billion light years, when they were emitted by the galaxy. 


The calculated values from the redshift data are according to the standard theoretical model of cosmology based on the FLRW metric and the Lambda-CDM expansion model.

I’m happy to offer some information which I hope will be helpful. I do now understand your question, and you have framed it very well.

I’ll give a short answer that also corrects a couple of misconceptions in your question. Let me know if this is not clear.  

You wrote:
-----------------------------------------
“Directly from the paper:

"Light that superluminally receding objects emit propagates towards us with a local peculiar velocity of c, but since the recession velocity at that distance is greater than c, the total velocity of the light is away from us (Equation (20)). However, since the radius of the Hubble sphere increases with time, some photons that were initially in a superluminally receding region later find themselves in a subluminally receding region. They can therefore approach us and eventually reach us."

My very simple question is: Why does entering the Hubble Sphere automatically mean that we can now observe the superluminal objects.”
-----------------------------------------

Answer:

The quote from the paper describes the fact that outside the Hubble Sphere in superluminal space the peculiar velocity of the photons with a local velocity toward the earth at the velocity of c, has a recession velocity away from the earth greater than c. So the total velocity of the photons is away from the earth and they never get here.
On the other hand, the Hubble Sphere increases over time and takes some photons inside it that were previously outside it. Then, inside the Hubble Sphere, the peculiar velocity of the photons still have a local velocity toward the earth of c, but now the recession velocity away from the earth is less than c. So then the total velocity of the photons inside the Hubble Sphere is toward the earth, and they will eventually reach the earth and be observed.

-------------------------------------------------

I’ll correct a couple of misconceptions in your question that might confuse the issue.

1) You say:  “The radius of the Hubble Sphere increases at the speed of light.”
 
This is a common misconception. The radius of the Hubble Sphere separates subluminal space from superluminal space, and is therefore the distance from the earth where SPACE is expanding exactly at the speed of light,. But the HUBBLE SPHERE is a mathematical construct, not a physical object or surface, and it does not expand with space. It’s true that the Hubble Sphere increases in size over time, but not at the rate of expansion of the universe. In fact, it expands relatively more rapidly than the universe, and specifically not at the speed of light. That is essential to the fact that the Hubble Sphere expands outward and takes within itself photons that are originally outside it.

2) You say:    “As you can see the light is still moving away from us but slower than the rate of expansion of the Hubble Sphere. This means that the light will enter the Hubble Sphere, but continue moving away from us.”

Light which is within the Hubble Sphere NEVER moves away from the earth. Light moves toward the earth at the universal constant speed of light, and within the Hubble Sphere, space is expanding (and carrying light photons with it) at LESS than the speed of light. So the net velocity of light inside the Hubble Sphere is ALWAYS toward the earth.

Acceleration of space would cause the Hubble to expand. But this is forgetting that the space outside the Hubble sphere is also expanding at an accelerating rate. So the light from the galaxy would never cross into the Hubble sphere. Furthermore, since the rate of expansion is accelerating, the Hubble sphere would actually be shrinking. Imagine this with the following example. Suppose that expansion is happening at a rate of 1mm/s per meter, so that two objects 10 meters apart have space expanding at about 10mm/s between them. Now suppose you increase the rate of expansion to 2mm/s per meter. Now it would only take a distance of 5 meters between two objects in order to achieve a space expansion rate of 10mm/s between them. The Hubble limit from one object to the other has shrunk. However, if the rate of expansion was decelerating, like in the Friedmann model, then the Hubble sphere would grow in size.

If you’re going to try to debunk the nature of science and the scientific method (which you seek to deprecate and trivialize with the cutesy label “sciencism”) as being illogical, then you really should try to actually make some logical sense with your argument.
 
You proclaim that it’s not “logical” for an observable universe that has existed for about 13 billion years to have a radius of about 46 billion years. In fact, that would be illogical only if the expansion of space were limited by the speed of light. But it isn’t. The essential point of this video, and the absolutely irrefutable proof of the redshift data and the standard candle measurements of distances using Type Ia supernovae, shows that the expansion of space at great distances is much greater than the speed of light relative to the earth-based observer. So 13 billion years have passed since the big bang, and the observable universe (expanding faster than light) now has a radius of 46 billion light years. Maybe you think it’s illogical that light from the edge of the observable universe at a distance of 46 billion light years could ever get to the earth in the 13 billion years since the big bang. Yes that WOULD be illogical. But that’s not what the science of cosmology says about what makes the “Observable Universe” observable. The Observable Universe we see today is observed in redshifted light from the distant past, when the universe was much smaller and the objects we now see were much closer to the earth. The current 46 billion year distance is a calculated value of the present distance using the FLRW metric and the LambdaCDM expansion model, based on redshift data from the past. The galaxies at these current distances are now far beyond the Hubble Sphere and the Particle Horizon, and the light they emit today will never be seen on earth at any time in the future. The expanding universe has carried them far beyond the Observable Universe of the far distant future.

The universe is expanding uniformly in all three spatial dimensions, and by the “Cosmological Principle” is both homogeneous and isotropic on a sufficiently large cosmic scale. So the universe is the same wherever you are, and looks the same in whatever direction you look.

The metric expansion of that homogeneous and isotropic universe means that everything is moving away from everything else, and the objects farther away from any point are moving away from that point faster than the objects that are closer to it. This means that any observer in space, wherever he is, sees himself at the center of a uniform expansion that he observes as he looks out in any direction from his point of observation.

There are two possibilities as to the ultimate dimensions of the universe. It may be bounded or unbounded…..finite or infinite. If it’s infinite in size, it cannot possibly have a geometric center, because there are no boundaries for anything to be the center OF. The other possibility is that the universe might be finite. But even if that’s so, the boundaries are so far beyond the Observable Universe that we can never observe them, and they cannot possibly have any physical effect within the Observable Universe. So while there might in theory be a geometric center to a finite universe, there is no way to identify where it is, and no preferred location within the Observable Universe.

So we are left with the fact that our Observable Universe is a spherical volume of space that we’re at the center of, since we see the same large scale universe at the same distance in whatever direction we point our telescopes. And since the nature of expanding space makes every point of observation appear to be the origin of the expansion, then we are not only at the center of our Observable Universe, we inevitably see ourselves at the origin of the expansion of that Observable Universe.

Therefore the theory of cosmology is based on an observer who is at rest at the center of the expanding Observable Universe. Since there is no identifiable center to the universe, and since every point in the universe appears to be the center of the expansion, then for both theoretical and observational purposes, the observer on earth is at the center of the universe.

Think of a person riding a bicycle with headlamps at the front and back of the bike.  If the person is traveling at 13mph, the light emitted from the front of the bike is not traveling away at the speed of light plus 13 mph, the light is traveling away at the speed of light.  Likewise, the light shining out the back of the bike is not traveling at the speed of light minus 13 mph, it leaves at the speed of light.  The speed of light doesn't change as you accelerate, just your perception of time (of course the time shift that happens while riding a bicycle is imperceptible).

@dezent: In Special Relativity, you have to be careful with reference frames. When you talk about two beams approaching each other at close to the speed of light, you probably mean that each beam is moving at close to the speed of light relative to a stationary observer. While he would then infer a closing velocity greater than light speed, that would not constitute a physical velocity through spacetime in the sense of Special Relativity. The issue is the speed of each moving beam as viewed from the reference frame of the other beam. To find the speed of one relative to the reference frame of  the other you have to use the Special Relativity Velocity Addition formula:

V =  (V1 + V2) / [1 + (V1 X V2) / c^2]

Regardless of the individual velocities relative to a stationary observer, the velocity of one when viewed from the reference frame of the other can never exceed the speed of light.

A curious side-effect of the metric expansion of the universe, something that you could have touched, is that light travels "faster" than c in an expanding universe.
It never travels faster than c locally, but when its travel distance and time is measured over very long distances (on an expanding universe), we see that it has traveled "faster" than c along that distance (even though it never surpassed c locally).

This can be explained with the analogy of a snail advancing on a stretching rubber band: Even if the snail can never advance faster than a certain speed, if it travels on the rubber band in the direction of the stretching, it will be traveling faster than its own local speed. Basically, the rubber band carries the snail with itself. Likewise space "carries" light with itself as it expands.

This also gives an answer to the apparently paradoxical question of whether the snail will ever reach the other end of the rubber band if the band is being stretched faster than the snail. For example, if the snail travels 1 meter per second and you are stretching the end of the rubber band at 1.1 meters per second, will the snail reach the end? And the answer is yes. At no point did the snail travel over 1 m/s with respect to the rubber band, yet it reaches the end.

However, there's a limit. If you stretch the rubber band faster than a certain speed, the snail will never reach the end. The same's true for the universe and light.

@ Aamin Gem: Although you didn't allow replies to your comments, you asked a question about the relative motion of two objects moving at relativistic velocities.
 
The recession velocity of objects moving outward with the Hubble Flow (expansion of space) is not the same thing as the local relative motion of objects through spacetime. The recession velocity is solely due to the change in the scale factor of space, and at great distances may be much larger than the speed of light.

However, the relative motion of massive objects through spacetime is governed by Special Relativity and can never reach or exceed the speed of light. The relative motion of two objects moving at relativistic velocities (a significant fraction of the speed of light) is determined in the reference frame of one object relative to the other, as calculated using the Special Relativity velocity addition relationship. For the example you gave involving two objects, each with a velocity of 0.6c (relative to an observer in his own rest frame), and moving away from each other, the velocity of each object relative to the reference frame of the other is 0.88c .

The formula is:  V =  (V1 + V2) / [1 + (V1 X V2) / c^2] , where V is the motion of either one of the objects relative to the reference frame of the other. Note that if V1 and V2 (the individual velocities relative to an observer) are much less than c, then the V1 X V2/c^2 term effectively goes to zero and V is simply the sum of the two individual velocities as a close non-relativistic approximation.

This video implies that if the universe is finite, then the Big Bang did have a centralized location.  This is not necessarily true.  If the universe is finite and unbounded, then the Big Bang (which is an expansion of space, not an explosion in space) still would have happened everywhere at once.  The common analogy is to use the surface of a balloon to represent the universe, and inflate it.  There is no place on that surface (and therefore the universe) where the expansion is taking place.  The difficulty with these analogies is that the surface area of the sphere is 2-D curved around a third physical dimension, where the universe is a volume (possibly) curved around a fourth physical dimension.   Since it is so difficult to think in 4-D terms (hypershpere, for example) these analogies usually have to drop a physical dimension for comprehension purposes.  
I also dislike the phrase, "The universe is (or was) expanding faster than the speed of light.  True, two objects within the universe can have relative velocities to each other greater than 'c' thanks to the expansion of space, but it implies that expansion is linear...  The Hubble Constant is how fast something is moving away per unit of time per how far away it already is.  A rate is not anything like linear movement, because of this reason.  

Still, overall this is a good video, and I admit I'm being very fussy about these particular issues that I brought up.   For an educational tool for people with little understanding of cosmology, it explains the concepts it is intended to very well.

There are many similar questions here about why the Hubble Sphere is expanding, even though the expansion of the universe is accelerating.

The radius of the Hubble Sphere is defined as c/H, where c is the speed of light, and H is the Hubble "Constant". H is getting smaller, so the Hubble Sphere is getting larger. (Yeah, it's not really "constant".)
H is not simply a measure of the expansion of the universe. Such a number would be measured in km/sec, for example. But H is km/sec divided by the distance in  megaparsecs. H ~ 69 km/sec/Mpc. So the Hubble Sphere can get larger even with an accelerating expansion as long as H changes more slowly than the universe expands, which is where we are right now.
Google Sean Carroll's Dark Energy FAQ for more info.

This video was great apart from one /serious/ problem.  The Hubble volume actually /decreases/ when the universe's expansion is /accelerating/.  This is the reason why inflation solves the flatness and horizon problems - the accelerated expansion decreased the Hubble volume* in the early universe to small volumes which are roughly in thermal equilibrium.  The following decelerating expansion increased our Hubble volume, which is why wavelengths have been entering the horizon that had exited during inflation.  However, the past half-a-universe of time or so, the expansion has been accelerating and our Hubble volume is decreasing again as we gradually enter another inflationary era.  This is why people say Dark Energy domination eventually makes a universe a lonely place - the volume of space which isn't receding from us at the speed of light eventually becomes small.

*actually H=constant in inflation and wavelengths are stretched, but the relative effect is the same as I have said above.
